data.text: Seatpost / Saddle Connection Screw Broke on a Bike Tour

Has anyone have their saddle screw break on them (the one that actually holds the saddle on the post)? Mine just did and, fortunately, I wasn't on a tour and only 3 miles from home. But, I had to ride home standing up or sitting on my rear rack, which was pretty interesting. I was thinking that this situation would have sucked if I was far away as I don't carry a spare. It's just not something I ever thought would break. Now, when I go buy a new screw, I'm buying two and keeping one in the tool bag, just in case. But, I'm curious, does anyone know of a way to secure the saddle to the post with zip ties or something? Or, any other weird, wild, wacky solution to a mech problem that you'd like to share with this awesome group?

Yes, I had a seat bolt saddle bolt break on tour. Lucky I was only 10 miles from a town with a NAPA store. It was Bontrager post.. When I got home,, the LBS was incredulous. And not helpful.. They were a Trek dealer.. Now I only ride with two bolt seat posts. And no longer buy anything Bontrager.

data.text: Yeah it happens especially with the single-bolt models. Maybe carry a spare when you are touring. I've never heard of any really effective roadside fixes, most people just stand all the way home.

data.text: I too have had this happen once. I took out the seat post, found some scraps on the side of the road as I continued, such as rags, a board, etc. and was able to "pile" it all up to make something of a seat "cushion." I also had a rear rack, which helped considerably. It worked well enough to ride quite a few miles. These things do happen.

data.text: Another time I had the handlebars break in two, right at the mount. That took some hunting for junk along the roadside, but I did find enough things for a temporary fix. Fortunately, I had some stainless steel hose clamps and found a piece of broomstick that fit well enough. That was a fun day. I was so lucky I didn't crash when it snapped in two.

data.text: Yep, I had this problem on tour in Portugal. I had an inadequate thin long nut and bolt that worked sort off but I donâ€™t think would have lasted long. We went in and the mechanic had a rummage and finally found a very suitable bolt. He refused any payment but relented when I said it was for a beer. We went on our way rejoicing, small miracles do happen. I now always carry a spare bolt.
